annevk: So, to clarify: The tests you found failing in Firefox but succeeding in Safari & WebKit were (a) missing padding and (b) base64url decoding works. The case (a) seems to be in WPT; but looks like (b) is not even tested in wpt?
content.formatted_body: annevk: So, to clarify: The tests you found failing in Firefox but succeeding in Safari & WebKit were (a) missing padding and (b) base64url decoding works. The case (a) seems to be in WPT; but looks like (b) is not even tested in wpt?

content.body: freddy: could be, it would also be interesting to test base64 that has whitespace and whether implementations strip it or not (as they do for data: URLs and atob/btoa)
content.formatted_body: freddy: could be, it would also be interesting to test base64 that has whitespace and whether implementations strip it or not (as they do for data: URLs and atob/btoa)

content.body: Austin Keener: Chrome and Firefox are buggy, Safari does this correctly; hopefully it'll get addressed as part of Interop 2023
content.formatted_body: Austin Keener: Chrome and Firefox are buggy, Safari does this correctly; hopefully it'll get addressed as part of Interop 2023

content.body: Script files with whitespace or integrity metadata with whitespace?
freddy: hmm, I guess that naturally ends up failing due to how integrity is parsed
content.formatted_body: freddy: hmm, I guess that naturally ends up failing due to how integrity is parsed

content.body: well, we split multiple items of integrity metadata on spaces, so not sure if that's even expected to work
freddy: so maybe that cannot be tested
content.formatted_body: freddy: so maybe that cannot be tested

content.body: freddy: and I guess "spaces" there is HTML/Infra's definition of ASCII whitespace?
content.formatted_body: freddy: and I guess "spaces" there is HTML/Infra's definition of ASCII whitespace?

content.body: freddy: could still test \v then, but that's about it
content.formatted_body: freddy: could still test \v then, but that's about it

content.body: With the "missing padding" and base64url already working in other browsers, it seems unlikely that we can deprecate in Safari and Chrome. I consider just filing a bug for Firefox to support it
freddy: I kinda wish we could remove missing padding from base64 "default"
content.formatted_body: freddy: I kinda wish we could remove missing padding from base64 "default"

content.body: Do you want to drive a deprecation in Safari and Chrome?
Even forgiving base64 is stricter on padding than that
I want fewer base64 decoding options, yes; I'm not personally signing up for Chromium work
